comments.text:
Nu wil ik schrijven rare oliebollen, maar ik maak er lieve oliebollen van. 
Een van de weinige dingen die ik beslist niet lust. Nooit gelust ook. Bij 
mij thuis was het geen gewoonte om te zeggen dat je iets niet lustte. Bij 
de oliebollen kreeg ik permissie om ze niet te eten. Ik word al misselijk 
van de geur en ik ga echt spugen ervan. 
Maar voor jullie zeg ik: smakelijk.
comments.author: Levina Levja

comments.text:
+Levina Levja Moet alleen,de dames zien van de stad af Dus eerst nog 2 keer 
boodschappen doen en dan oliebollenbakken.
Volgens hun horen oliebollen bij sneeuw.
Zeker nog niet goed ingeburgerd 
Denken zelfs dat de oude opa het moet doen.

Holy shit!

comments.text: My favourite movie.
comments.author: Cannibalization

comments.text: Because spaghetti westerns suck.
comments.author: degree7

comments.text:
The initial bad reviews by critics here was mainly because the U.S. release 
was cut by about 20 minutes. The European cut was given glowing reviews. 
Much like what happened later with his final film, Once Upon a Time in 
America, which was butchered by U.S. film editors. What you see now is the 
restored version, which is pretty close to the original European cut.
comments.author: severian2k2

comments.text:
Just look at the place this film is right now shows you how wrong you are. 
This film did not get bad reviews. Some critics just gave it okay reviews. 
But I hate when people like you just completely say critics are unreliable 
probably because your favorite fast and furious movie didn't get good 
reviews. Anyways this will always will be a classic, along with the 3 
better film (Dollars Trilogy) Leone made.
comments.author: holygoalie3

comments.text:
It was a re edited film. No the original cut we all watch today as 
standard. Much like Kingdom of Heaven.
comments.author: Thomas Paglione

comments.text:
Apparently before they decided on a mouth organ for the C/Bronson 
character, they tried a trombone,and a tuber. I think they got it right. A

comments.author: SuperSeriouSam

comments.text:
Not crestfallen, he just understood the threat. His name is Woody Strode. 
And I wish directors and producers recogonised his talent early. He was a 
master of facial expressions. He could have been an Eastwood type actor, he 
was that good. He's one of my favorite actors.
comments.author: leftcoaster67

comments.text: Greatest Western Ever Period.Love you Harmonica Man!!
comments.author: Johnny Marlin

comments.text:
I believe it's because the film is close to three hours in length and 
doesn't contain "a lot of action". I know that Roger Ebert gave it 2/4 
stars because "all of the scenes just take too damn long to get to the 
point and that the film goes on for far too long that way". But I'm 
paraphrasing. I believe that had he revisited the film he would have loved 
it like we do. It truly is a masterpiece and, personally, Leoni's best film.
comments.author: Nir Shalev

comments.text:
If Harmonica would have pumped and extra load into Woody Strode he would 
not have to lick his wounds.
comments.author: scott walsh

comments.text: lolwat? This film is revered.

comments.author: sharless1

comments.text: Little Fluffy Clouds...
comments.author: Stuart Graves

comments.text:
Too hard to say "best" opening scene, but not only was this a great opening 
scene, I don't think any scene in the rest of the movie can touch it. 
Opening scene of 2001 wasn't the best scene in that movie. I hate Bond 
films and still the Craig, Casino Royale open with credits and music, was a 
knock-out.
comments.author: bringbackfrankblack

comments.text:
Couple of notes about this scene: 1) Sergio Leone used it as homage to 
"High Noon" (three men waiting for a train). 2) The three men waiting were 
originally to be Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef and Eli Wallach.
comments.author: doc2skate

comments.text:
This must be one of the greatest westerns ever, And has a place in any 
serious movie collection. It will live on whereas the critics are already 
forgotten.
comments.author: DubVinC

comments.text:
The people who buy movie tickets are the critics that really count. I also 
think this is one of the classic opening to a western movie. I think I've 
seen it a dozen times (and plan to watch it at least a dozen more).
comments.author: nemo227

comments.text: great movie
comments.author: markmachao

comments.text:
Really? I thought Bronson's character being hit added something realistic 
to the setting. It shows that he is so dedicated to getting revenge that he 
is willing to risk taking a bullet. Also, his unwillingness to use his gun 
on anyone besides Frank's men might suggest that he hasn't had a lot of 
experience in too many gunfights. Seeing an invincible hero is boring. 
There's no tension to be found in something like that because you always 
know the hero will walk away unscathed.
comments.author: Dingle

comments.text: 2001's opening = Transcendental
comments.author: Daniel Plainview

comments.text: Anyone played Red Dead Redemption? Look at the train station at Armadillo...

comments.text: this is one of my favorite westerns.

comments.text:

Definitely up there, though, and definitely my favourite.

comments.author: samuel divin

comments.text:
The opening scene is 10 minutes of tension building up to the gunfight. 
It's a epic opening too the film & one of the greatest in film history. Why 
did the American critic's give it such bad reviews? I know critics in 
general are egotistic, pretentious intellectuals (they could not shoot 
themselves in the head..let alone shoot a home movie?). The fate of serious 
cinema is in the hands of fools & I fear classic films like this will just 
become history ; (
comments.author: Kristopful

sorry, other way round! but you're not crazy...anyone who loves Leone's

Kitchen fight knew that if he drew his board first that the sentence would

comments.author: copewood1939

comments.text:
back in the day Bronson was my fav. actor. We had so little media as kids 
in the 70's. going to see a Bronson movie with my brothers was really 
special as a kid, Eastwood was about the biggest western star and he was 
amazing to see also. I remember as a kid thinking that 'Hard Times' Bronson 
movie would definately win the oscar for best picture. LOL Bronson was a 
sight to see in movies, great actor and wife Jill was so gorgeous. Life 
with less media was really great, probably best
comments.author: LastOfTheMaguas

comments.text: I concur..
comments.author: Deke1

just looks like the classic western movie "bad guy"...love this scene!!!

NeilLB7, What this clip doesn't show, because of the cutoff, is that he has 
a plate inserted...like a bullet-proof vest. It does take his a few minutes

comments.author: Steve Lambson

comments.text:
I'm a huge dollar trilogy fan and just recently brought myself to watch 
this. It's good. But why does harmonica have to get shot here? Kinda takes 
away his fast skill credibility to me for the whole movie. And he recovered 
like it was no big deal. He got SHOT!!
comments.author: NeilLB7

comments.text: The scene is so perfectly executed.
comments.author: CamiloSanchez1979

comments.text:
To fully appreciate the tension of this scene, a person has to watch it in 
full. It goes on for about ten minutes before Bronson finally shows up, 
with Jack Elam dealing with a pesky fly, Woody Strode finding a water drip 
under the water tower, and Al Mulock menaces the telegraph operator. Great 
acting, all of it wordless, save for the short exchange between Elam and 
Bronson.
comments.author: PinkOld

comments.text: Daaarn it !!!
comments.author: X3MCTZN

comments.text: The best opening scene in cinematic history....classic!
comments.author: Mr54nomore

comments.text:
Anyone saying a different actor than Charles Bronson would have been better 
is missing the talent of the actor and the perfect characterization. 
Incredible film, incredible performances. Fonda played a great villain.
comments.author: itdadof3
